awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activities of Professors Pran Nath, Brent D. Nelson, and Tomasz R. Taylor at Northeastern University.

Thus far, data from the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) has been highly successful and has led to the discovery of the Higgs boso, which was the last missing piece of the Standard Model of particle physics.  However, future data expected from the LHC will explore the nature of physics beyond the Standard Model.  As part of their research, Professors Nath, Nelson, and Taylor will conduct studies aimed at finding clues of such new physics in upcoming data from the LHC and well as in astrophysical data.  In their work, Professors Nath, Nelson, and Taylor will use models based on a symmetry known as "supersymmetry" which relates particles of different spins to each other, and on string theory, an approach to physics at very high energies which purports to unify all forces of nature, including gravity.   This area of research serves the national interest as it advances our knowledge of the fundamental laws of nature at the frontiers of current knowledge.  In addition, there is a strong educational component to this research.  Several Ph.D. thesis students will be involved in these research projects.  Likewise, Professors Nath, Nelson, and Taylor will disseminate their research through publications, conference and workshop presentations, and popular lectures.  In addition, an important element of the proposal is "TheoryNet".   This is an outreach program consisting of direct interactions between Boston-Area theorists and high-school students, through lecture presentations and demonstrations.

More technically, Professors Nath, Nelson, and Taylor will conduct studies of dark matter in unified models based on supergravity and strings which contain possible dark-matter candidates, including those in a hidden sector.   They will also conduct further theoretical work related to unified models based on strings and F-theory and they will conduct further investigations into the structure of string amplitudes.   They will also investigate areas where particle theory overlaps with cosmology, specifically in the study of inflation and dark energy, and search for a unified framework for both.  Finally, they will develop strategies to search for new physics in precision analyses which have the potential to probe physics at scales far beyond the reach of current or future accelerators.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The major outcomes of the work done under the grant relate to exploration of physics beyond the standard models of particle theory and of cosmology. This is necessitated by the fact that the current standard models  are found inadequate in explaining all data.  The standard model of particle physics is unable to explain the existence of dark matter and dark energy in the universe  and further it breaks down above the TeV energy region while the standard model of cosmology is found inadequate to explain anomalies such as the Hubble tension. These issues were broadly addressed on various fronts in the work done under the grant. Thus on the particle front it was shown that the if the Fermilab result  on the muon anomaly arises from supersymmetry, then supersymmetry must be observed in the next generation of experiment at the Large Hadron Collider, lifting tension on the standard model. Further, it was shown that new degrees of freedom arising from the hidden sector could alleviate the Hubble tension.  Another major outcome related to development of  cosmologically consistent evolution of dark sectors and the visible sector taking account of  couplings among them.  The analysis showed that the assumption  commonly made in the previous literature of their separately independent evolution is invalid even in the presence of feeble couplings. Using this formalism it was shown that a dark gauge boson exchange, as a fifth dark force,  can fit dark matter cross sections from galaxy scales where the dark matter is collisional to the scales of galaxy clusters where the dark matter is collision-less. The formalism was also applied to explain the absorption profile of the 21-centimeter hydrogen like observed by the EDGES experiment which cannot be explained by the current standard  $\Lambda$CDM model of cosmology.  Further outcomes related to the  investigation of  four-dimensional scattering amplitudes transformed into the so-called celestial boost basis. Applications of it were made to Yang-Mills theory coupled to scalar dilatons, with the dilatons created by a point-like source. With the dilatons coupled in a minimal way to the gluon field strength tensor resembling low-energy limit of heterotic superstrings, such a source creates gluons. Multi-gluon amplitudes with a single dilaton source insertion can then be constructed from the on-shell scattering amplitudes involving a number of gluons and one massive dilaton. Such amplitudes are of interest since they are similar to the decays of Higgs particle into hadronic jets. Other outcomes related to analyses of stochastic gravitational wave backgrounds produced by confining phase transitions in dark Yang-Mills sectors. This was done for several concrete simple Lie groups, followed by computation of their gravitational wave signal. For all gauge groups considered, it was  found that the gravitational signal is accessible to gravitational detectors such as BBO and DECIGO.
